t: Job 28
Interlude: Where Wisdom Is Found
There*pn is a mine for silver and*ld a place where gold is refined.
Iron*ln is taken from the earth, and*ld copper is smelted from ore.
Mortals*ln put an end to the darkness; they*ld search out the farthest recesses for*ld ore in the blackest darkness.
Far*ln from human dwellings they cut a shaft, in*ld places untouched by human feet; far*ld from other people they dangle and sway.
The*ln earth, from which food comes, is*ld transformed below as by fire;
lapis*ln lazuli comes from its rocks, and*ld its dust contains nuggets of gold.
No*ln bird of prey knows that hidden path, no*ld falcon’s eye has seen it.
Proud*ln beasts do not set foot on it, and*ld no lion prowls there.
People*ln assault the flinty rock with their hands and*ld lay bare the roots of the mountains.
They*ln tunnel through the rock; their*ld eyes see all its treasures.
They*ln search the sources of the rivers and*ld bring hidden things to light.
But*pn where can wisdom be found? Where*ld does understanding dwell?
No*ln mortal comprehends its worth; it*ld cannot be found in the land of the living.
The*ln deep says, “It is not in me”; the*ld sea says, “It is not with me.”
It*ln cannot be bought with the finest gold, nor*ld can its price be weighed out in silver.
It*ln cannot be bought with the gold of Ophir, with*ld precious onyx or lapis lazuli.
Neither*ln gold nor crystal can compare with it, nor*ld can it be had for jewels of gold.
Coral*ln and jasper are not worthy of mention; the*ld price of wisdom is beyond rubies.
The*ln topaz of Cush cannot compare with it; it*ld cannot be bought with pure gold.
Where*pn then does wisdom come from? Where*ld does understanding dwell?
It*ln is hidden from the eyes of every living thing, concealed*ld even from the birds in the sky.
Destruction*ln and Death say, “Only*ld a rumor of it has reached our ears.”
God*ln understands the way to it and*ld he alone knows where it dwells,
for*ln he views the ends of the earth and*ld sees everything under the heavens.
When*ln he established the force of the wind and*ld measured out the waters,
when*ln he made a decree for the rain and*ld a path for the thunderstorm,
then*ln he looked at wisdom and appraised it; he*ld confirmed it and tested it.
And*ln he said to the human race, “The*ld fear of the Lord—that is wisdom, and*ld to shun evil is understanding.”
